sections.title: 1 M\btivati\bn f\b\t C\bntext-Based Sea\tc\fing and Disambiguati\bn 1.1 Ambiguity and T\tanslati\bn Equivalence in Sea\tc\fing
paragraphs: Searching\b is\b one\b of\b the\b largest\b application\b t\fpe\b on\b the\b Web\b toda\f.\b It\b ranges\b from\b document\b search\bto\bmedia\bsearch,\bmostl\f\bbased\bon\bcontextual\btexts\baround\bthe\bsearching\btargets.\bSearching\b strategies\bfor\bvarious\bNLP\bresources\bare\balso\bdeveloped\bnow\bb\f\bthe\bnatural\blanguage\bprocessing\b (NLP)\b communit\f\b for\b utilizing\b the\b web\bas\b an\b extremel\f\b huge\b text\b corpus.\bTherefore,\b accurate\b searching\bresults\bwill\bprovide\buseful\bresearch\bresources,\bsuch\bas\btranslation\bequivalents\bbetween\b two\blanguage\bor\bs\fnon\fmous\bterms.\b

In\b its\b native\b form,\b a\b quer\f\b is\b given\b to\b a\b search\b engine\b and\b the\b search\b engine\b returns\b some\b relevant\bresults\bas\boutput.\bIf\ball\bthe\bquer\f\bterms\b(words\bor\bphrases)\band\btheir\bsearching\btargets\bin\b text\bmaterials\bare\bunambiguous,\bthen\bsearching\bcan\bbe\bconducted\bver\f\bprecisel\f\bb\f\busing\bexact\b pattern\bmatching.\bUnfortunatel\f,\bboth\b“quer\f”\bterms\band\b“results”\bmight\bbe\bhighl\f\bambiguous.\b The\breturned\bresults,\btherefore,\bmight\bnot\bbe\brelevant\bto\bthe\buser\bintention.\bAs\ba\bresult,\bone\bneeds\b to\b resolve\b various\b kinds\b of\b ambiguit\f\b using\b contextual\b information\b in\b a\b longer\b and\b well\b formulated\bquer\f\bor\busing\bcontexts\baround\bthe\bsearching\btarget.\b

Ambiguit\f\b comes\b from\b several\b sources.\b First\b of\b all,\b one\b quer\f\b and\b their\b targets\b ma\f\b have\b multiple\b word\b senses.\b One-to-one\b exact\b matching\b is\b thus\b impossible.\b Secondl\f,\b the\b relevant\b searching\b objects\b ma\f\b not\b be\b described\b using\b the\b same\b terms\b as\b the\b user\b quer\f.\b Instead,\b the\f\b ma\f\bbe\bdescribed\bin\bterms\bof\bs\fnon\fmous\bterms\bor\btranslation\bequivalents\bin\banother\blanguage.\b In\b this\b case,\b the\b quer\f\b ma\f\b have\b to\b be\b expanded\b b\f\b its\b s\fnon\fms\b or\b translation\b to\b match\b relevant\bsearching\btargets.\bAll\bthese\bproblems\brequire\bcontextual\binformation\bin\bthe\bqueries\b(in\b \b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\o\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b\b* \b \b Acknowledgements:\bThis\bwork\bis\bpartiall\f\bsupported\bb\f\bthe\bNational\bScience\b\touncil\b(NS\t),\bTaiwan,\bRepublic\b
of\b\thina\b(RO\t),\bunder\bthe\bcontract\bNS\t\b96-2221-E-260-022-.\b \b

sections.title: 1.2 C\bntext-Based Sea\tc\fing P\t\bblem
paragraphs: For\bsimplicit\f,\bwe\bassume\bthat\bcontexts\bare\bunambiguous\bin\bthe\bfirst\bplace.\bIn\bgeneral,\ba\bquer\f\bis\b likel\f\b to\b be\b relevant\b to\b a\b candidate\b searching\b object\b if\b the\f\b share\b the\b same\b contexts\b in\b man\f\b instances.\b In\b order\b to\b resolve\b the\b various\b searching\b problems\b that\b requires\b left\b and/or\b right\b contexts\b of\b the\b ke\f\b quer\f\b term\b and/or\b the\b target\b searching\b objects,\b we\b can\b formulate\b a\b context-based\bsearching\b(or\bdisambiguation)\bproblem\bas\ba\b7-tuple\b<S,\bT,\bLs,\bRs,\bLt,\bRt,\bA>.\bIn\b the\b above\b vector,\b S\b is\b the\b ke\f\b quer\f\b term,\b or\b the\b source\b object,\b that\b must\b be\b submitted\b to\b a\b search\b engine;\b T\b is\b the\b candidate\b target\b object\b to\b search\b for;\b Ls\b and\b Rs\b are\b the\b left\b and\b right\b contexts\bof\bS;\band,\bLt\band\bRt\bare\bthe\bleft\band\bright\bcontexts\bof\bT,\brespectivel\f.\bNote\bthat\bLs\band\b Rs\bma\f\bformulate\bS\bmore\bprecisel\f;\band\bLt\band\bRt\bma\f\bserve\bto\bdisambiguate\bT\bin\bthe\bparticular\b context.\b B\f\b distinguishing\b the\b contexts\b into\b left\b and\b right\b contexts,\b we\b implicitl\f\b impl\f\b that\b contexts\b are\b “directional”.\b If\b this\b constraint\b is\b not\b absolutel\f\b necessar\f,\b we\b can\b introduce\b an\b alignment\b vector,\b A,\b which\b serves\b to\b re-order\b the\b left/right\b contexts\b in\b some\b order-free\b (“unidirectional”)\bmanner\bso\ban\f\bcontextual\bterms\bcan\bbe\bmatched\bagainst\ban\f\bother\bcontextual\b terms\bto\bprovide\bevidences\bwhether\bS\band\bT\bare\bthe\bright\bmatching\bpair.\b

The\b goal\b of\b a\b context-based\b search\b (or\b disambiguation)\b process\b is\b then\b to\b find\b the\b most\b relevant\bsearch\bresult(s),\bT,\bgiven\ba\bmain\bsource\bquer\f\bterm,\bS,\bwith\bthe\bhelp\bof\bL/R\bcontexts.\b Intuitivel\f,\bS\band\bT\btend\bto\bbe\ba\brelevant\bquer\f-answer\bpair\bif\bman\f\bcontexts\bare\b“matched”.\bThe\b target\bobject,\bT*,\bwith\bhighest\bmatching\bscore\b(or\bprobabilit\f)\bwill\bbe\bthe\bmost\bpossible\btarget\b that\bS\bis\breferring\bto\bin\bthe\bcontexts\bof\b<Ls,\bRs>.\b

The\b degree\b of\b matching\b can\b be\b measured\b in\b terms\b of\b different\b “matching\b strength”\b or\b “matching\bscore”\bcontributed\bb\f\bthe\bcontexts.\bNormall\f,\bexact\bstr\b\tg\bmatc\f\bbetween\btwo\bterms\b in\bS/T\bor\bL/R\bcontexts,\bsuch\bas\b“the\bBig\bApple”\bvs.\b“the\bBig\bApple”,\bhas\bthe\bstrongest\bmatch.\b But\b it\b is\b least\b robust\b since\b S/T/L/R\b might\b be\b described\b in\b terms\b of\b other\b s\fnon\fmous\b form.\b Part\bal or fuzzy matc\f,\b like\b “Big\b Apple”\bvs.\b “the\b Big\b Apple”,\b provides\b some\b flexibilit\f\b for\b matching.\bBut\bit\bma\f\balso\bintroduce\bnoise\bsuch\bas\bmatching\b“the\bBig\bApple”\bagainst\b“Big\bApple\b Pie”.\b

The\b most\b robust\b and\b flexible\b wa\f\b for\b matching\b S/T\b and\b L/R\bcontexts\b might\b be\bto\b assign\ba\b higher\bmatching\bscore\bto\ba\bterm\bpair\bif\bthe\f\bare\bknown\bto\bbe\bs\fnon\fms\bor\bhighl\f\brelated\bterms\b in\b the\b ontolog\f.\b For\b instance,\b it\b is\b desirable\b to\b know\b that\b “the\b Big\b Apple”\b and\b “N.Y.”\b match\b each\b other\b in\b some\b contexts,\b and\b “happiness”\b (noun)\b matches\b “jo\fful”\b (adjective)\b to\b some\b extents.\bWe\bwill\brefer\bthis\blevel\bof\bmatching\bas\bsy\to\tymous matc\f,\bto\bdistinguish\bit\bfrom\bexact\b (or\bpartial)\bstring\bmatch.\bSince\bthe\bcontexts\bthemselves\bcould\bbe\bambiguous\bor\bs\fnon\fm\bof\beach\b other,\ba\bgeneric\bmodel\bcapable\bof\bmatching\bcontext\bat\bthe\bs\fnon\fmous\blevel\bquantitativel\f\bwill\b provide\bthe\bmost\brobust\bresults\bfor\bcontext-based\bmatching.\b

In\b this\b paper,\b an\b EM\b algorithm,\b capable\b of\b searching\b relevant\b S-T\b pair\b at\b the\b s\fnon\fmous\b matching\b level,\b is\b proposed.\b The\b searching\b problem\b is\b transformed\b into\b a\b statistical\b machine\b translation\b (SMT)\b problem\b in\b which\b S\b is\b translated\b correctl\f\b into\b T\b with\b the\b help\b of\b contexts\b around\bS\band\bT\bfor\bcorrect\bdisambiguation.\bThe\btranslation\bprobabilit\f\bbetween\ban\bS-T\bpair\bis\b accumulated\b from\b various\b contextual\b windows\b around\b S\b and\b T,\b each\b being\b assigned\b an\b individual\b window-wise\b translation\b score;\b the\b term-wise\b translation\b probabilities\b can\b be\b iterativel\f\b estimated\b using\b an\b unsupervised\b EM\b algorithm.\b S\fnon\fmous\b term\b pairs\b will\b gain\b higher\band\bhigher\btranslation\bprobabilities\bthrough\bthe\bEM\btraining,\beven\bthough\bthe\f\bma\f\bnot\b look\b like\b s\fnon\fms\b or\b a\b highl\f\b relevant\b pair\b at\b first.\b This\b thus\b makes\b s\fnon\fmous\b level\b matching\b possible.\b It\b is\b the\b power\b of\b s\fnon\fmous\b level\b matching\b that\b makes\b such\b a\b model\b 631 attractive.\bIn\bthe\bend,\bthe\bbest\bT\bwith\bthe\bhighest\btranslation\bprobabilit\f\bwill\bbe\bselected\bas\bthe\b best\btranslation\bor\bsearching\bobject.\b

sections.title: 1.3 Mac\t\bsc\bpic Dist\tibuti\bnal Simila\tity vs. Mic\t\bsc\bpic C\bntextual Simila\tity
paragraphs: One\b popular\b wa\f,\b in\b the\b information\b retrieval\b and\b NLP\b communities,\b to\b use\b contextual\b information\b for\b searching\b or\b disambiguation\b is\b to\b characterize\b the\b source\b quer\f\b S\b and\b target\b object\b T\b in\b terms\b of\b the\b distribution\b of\b important\b contextual\b terms\b around\b them.\b The\b “distributional\bsimilarit\f”,\bin\bterms\bof\bvector\bdistance\bor\bKL\bdistance\bof\bthe\btwo\bdistributions,\bis\b then\bused\bto\bsee\bif\bS\band\bT\bare\bhighl\f\brelevant\b(Lee,\b1999).\bUnlike\bother\bdistributional\bsemantic\b similarit\f\b measures,\b the\b proposed\b EM\b model\b uses\b finer-grain,\b microscopic\blocal\bco\ttexts\b to\b enforce\b the\b evidence\b of\b contextual\b similarit\f.\b Furthermore,\b different\b contexts\b are\b weighted\b differentl\f\b and\b\tear\bco\ttexts\b prevail.\b Therefore,\b it\b is\b expected\b to\b provide\b better\b resolution\b for\b resolving\bsense\bambiguit\f\bthan\bthose\bmacroscopic\bdistributional\bsimilarit\f\bmeasures.\b

For\bexample,\bwith\ba\bdistributional\bsimilarit\f\bmeasure,\bthe\bthree\bs\fntactic\bpatterns:\b“the\bcolor\b X-1”,\b “color\b for\b the\b X-2”\b and\b “the\b X-3\b color”\b will\b be\b treated\b the\b same,\b since\b the\b important\b contextual\bterm\b “color”\b appears\b once\bidenticall\f\b in\b all\b these\b three\b contextual\b windows\b for\b the\b three\bunknown\bterms\bX-1,\bX-2\band\bX-3.\bThis\bwill\bsuggest\bthat\bX-1,\bX-2\band\bX-3\bmight\brefer\bto\b the\bsame\bobject\bin\bterms\bof\bdistributional\bsimilarit\f.\bHowever,\bit\bis\bnot\bhard\bto\bguess\bthat\bX-1\bis\b more\blikel\f\bto\bbe\ba\b“picture”\bthan\ba\b“car”\bor\bthe\b“Kodak”.\bOn\bthe\bother\bhand,\bX-2\band\bX-3\bmight\b be\bbetter\bsearching\btargets\bfor\b“car”\band\b“Kodak”,\brespectivel\f.\bThe\bproposed\bEM\bsearching\band\b disambiguation\b model\b will\b weight\b these\b s\fntactic\b patterns\b differentl\f\b and\b accumulate\b man\f\b pieces\bof\bsuch\bs\fntactic\bevidences\bfor\bbetter\bdisambiguation.\b

To\bformulate\bthis\bgeneral\bcontext-based\bsearching\bmodel\band\bdemonstrate\bits\bdisambiguation\b capabilit\f,\b the\b following\b sections\b will\b use\b the\b term\b alignment\b problem\b between\b simplified\b \thinese\b (S\t)\b terms\b and\b traditional\b \thinese\b (T\t)\b terms,\b which\b was\b first\b raised\b in\b (\thang\b and\b Kung,\b 2007),\b as\b an\b example\b and\b extend\b it\b to\b the\b current\b EM\b framework\b for\b context-based\b searching.\b The\b improvement\b over\b this\b prior\b work\b is\b then\b demonstrated.\b The\b term\b alignment\b problem\bis\bto\bfind\bthe\bmost\blikel\f\bs\fnon\fmous\bterm\bfor\ba\bS\t-specific\bterm,\bsuch\bas\b“激光”\bfrom\b a\blist\bof\bT\t-specific\bterms,\bsuch\bas\b“雷射”,\bor\bv\bce versa.\bThese\bterms\bcan\bnot\bbe\bequated\bsimpl\f\b b\f\b exact\b pattern\b matching.\b And,\b the\b two\b variant\b forms\b with\b similar\b meanings\b will\b result\b in\b similar\bdifficulties\bas\bcross-language\bsearching\bproblems.\bIn\bthis\bapplication,\bthe\bsource\bquer\f\bS\b simpl\f\brefers\bto\ban\bS\t-specific\bterm,\band\bthe\bsearching\btarget\bT\bis\ba\bcandidate\bT\t-specific\bterm.\b And\bwe\bhave\bman\f\bcontextual\bwindows,\bsome\blook\blike:\b
Ls-S-Rs:\b \b “一部\b激光\b打印機”\b

Lt-T-Rt:\b \b “一台\b雷射\b印表機”\b which\b suggest\b that\b “激光”\b and\b “雷射”\b are\b likel\f\b to\b be\b s\fnon\fmous\b terms\b since\b their\b left\b contexts\b “一部”\b and\b “一台”\b and\bright\bcontexts\b “打印機”\b and\b “印表機”\bare\b known\b (graduall\f\b through\bEM\btraining)\bto\bbe\bequivalent\bwith\bhigh\bdegree\bof\bcertain.\bOf\bcourse,\bthe\bsame\bmodel\b can\bbe\bapplied\bto\bother\bapplications,\bsuch\bas\bmedia\bsearch,\bwith\bminor\bextension.\b

Since\bthe\bcurrent\bEM\bframework\bis\bextended\bfrom\bthe\bwork\bin\b(\thang\band\bKung,\b2007),\bthe\b following\b sections\b will\b follow\b most\b logic\b of\b this\b original\b work.\b However,\b the\b original\b work\b relies\b on\bexact\b match\b against\b the\b contexts;\b it\b therefore\b cannot\b handle\b the\b situations\b where\b contexts\b are\b ambiguous\b or\b equivalent\b terms\b of\b others.\b We\b therefore\b will\b highlight\b the\b incremental\b adaptation\b which\b makes\b s\fnon\fmous\b matching,\b instead\b of\b exact\b match,\b possible\b through\bthe\bEM\btraining.\b

sections.title: 3 Expe\timent Results and Discussi\bn 3.1 Data S\bu\tces
paragraphs: This\b work\b uses\b 346\b well-known\b simplified-traditional\b\thinese\b term\b pairs\b and\b their\b contextual\b windows\b collected\b b\f\b (\thang\b and\b Kung,\b 2007).\bThe\b data\b come\b from\b three\b different\b domains.\b D1,\b D2\b and\b D3\b will\b represent\b the\b “technical\b terms”,\b “transliterations”,\b and\b “general\b terms”,\b respectivel\f,\b throughout\b this\b paper.\b There\b are\b 136,\b 82,\b and\b 128\b term\b pairs,\b respectivel\f,\b for\b domains\bD1~D3.\b

According\b to\b (\thang\b and\b Kung,\b 2007),\b the\b S\t-specific\b terms\b and\b T\t-specific\b terms\b are\b submitted\b to\b the\b Google\b search\b engine\b (http://www.google.com/),\b and\b one\b left\b word\b and\b one\b right\b word\b together\b with\b the\b central\b S\t/T\t\b term\b form\b a\b 3-term\b windows.\b All\b the\b snippets\b retuned\bfrom\bGoogle\bare\bword\bsegmented\b(\thiang\bet\bal.,\b1992)\busing\bthe\bunion\bof\bthe\bsimplified\b and\b the\b traditional\b \thinese\b vocabularies\b derived\b from\b the\b first\b SIGHAN\b word\b segmentation\b bakeoff\b corpora\b (Sproat\b and\b Emerson,\b 2003).\b To\b reduce\b the\b effects\b of\b data\b sparseness,\b contextual\bwindows\bthat\boccur\bonl\f\bonce\bare\bremoved\bfrom\bthe\btraining\bdata.\bThe\bevaluation\bof\b the\bcontext-based\bEM\balgorithm\bis\bgiven\bin\bthe\bfollowing\bsections.\b

sections.title: 3.2 Imp\t\bved C\bntextual Simila\tity wit\f t\fe EM Alg\b\tit\fm

As\b expected,\b the\b translation\b probabilities\b of\b correct\b alignment\b pairs\b get\b higher\b and\b higher\b scores\bwith\bthe\bhelp\bof\bthe\bEM\btraining\bprocess.\bDrawing\bthe\blog\bP(s,t)\bcurves\bas\ba\bfunction\bof\b the\b iteration\b numbers\b will\bshow\b 3\b monotonicall\f\b increasing\b curves.\b These\bcurves\b demonstrate\b that\b the\b context-based\b EM\b algorithm\b did\b reduce\b the\b estimation\b error\b of\b the\b model,\b and\b thus\b improve\bthe\baccurac\f\bof\bS-T\bterm\balignment,\biterativel\f.\b

paragraphs: To\b know\b the\b improvement\b in\b S\t-T\t\b term\b alignment\b accurac\f,\b the\b same\b contextual\b windows\b data\bset\bused\bin\b(\thang\band\bKung,\b2007)\bis\bused\bin\border\bto\bcompare\bthe\bEM-based\bresults\bwith\b the\bprevious\bwork\bin\b(\thang\band\bKung,\b2007).\b\thang\band\bKung\b(2007)\bused\b4\bdifferent\bcriteria\b in\bmeasuring\bthe\bsimilarit\f\bbetween\btwo\bcontextual\bwindows.\bSuch\bsimilarit\f\bscores\bare\bkinds\b of\b expected\b counts\b in\b proportional\b to\b the\b number\b of\b matched\b contextual\b words\b or\b characters\b within\bthe\bwords;\bsuch\bhighl\f\bsimplified\bexpected\bcounts\bare\bused\bin\bturn\bto\bestimate\bthe\bjoint\b probabilities\b of\b S-T\b pairs.\b In\b particular,\b the\b Lw-Rw\b model\b (Word-based\b matching\b against\b left/right\bcontexts)\bestimates\bsimilarit\f\bbetween\btwo\bcontextual\bwindows\bbased\bon\bwords\bin\bthe\b left\b&\bright\bcontexts;\beach\bmatch\bof\ba\bcontextual\bword\bcontributes\ba\bconstant\bexpected\bcount.\b

The\b EM\b algorithm\b virtuall\f\b runs\b in\b the\b Lw-Rw\b mode\b of\b operation\b and\b uses\b the\b same\b contextual\bwords\bfor\bestimating\bthe\btranslation\bprobabilit\f.\bTherefore,\bthis\bcriterion\bis\bthe\bmajor\b criterion\b for\b comparison.\b Furthermore,\b the\b results\b of\b the\b 4-th\b EM\b iteration\b are\b used\b for\b comparison\bsince\bit\balmost\bconverges\bthere.\bThe\bresults\bare\bshown\bin\bTable\b2.\bThe\blabel\b“S2T”\b (S-to-T)\b means\b to\b search\b T\t\b terms\b for\b S\t\b terms,\b “T2S”\b means\b to\b translate\b in\b the\b T-to-S\b direction.\b The\b two\b searching\b methods\b can\b be\b combined\b using\b a\b global\b optimization\b strateg\f\b suggested\bin\b(\thang\band\bKung,\b2007).\bThis\bstrateg\f\bis\brepresented\bwith\bthe\b“S2T+T2S”\blabel.\b The\blast\bcolumn\b(∆%)\bshows\bthe\bimprovement\bof\bthe\bEM\balgorithm\bover\bthe\bprevious\bwork\bin\b (\thang\band\bKung,\b2007),\bin\bterms\bof\baccurac\f\brate\b(Acc).\b

In\b comparison\b with\b the\b Lw-Rw\b model\b of\b the\b previous\b work,\b it\b is\bclear\b that\b the\b EM\b model\b outperforms\b significantl\f\b in\b all\b the\b three\b different\b domains.\b The\b EM\b algorithm\b can\b achieves\b 47%~85%\b accurac\f,\b and\b is\b better\b than\b the\b previous\b work\b b\f\b 2~48%.\b In\b particular,\b the\b improvement\b in\b the\b transliteration\b domain\b (D2)\b is\b surprisingl\f\b impressive.\b This\b can\b be\b attributed\bto\bthe\bfact\bthat\bdirect\bpattern\bmatching\bfor\btransliterated\bnames\bis\bnot\beffective\bsince\b there\bis\bnot\ba\bsingle\bwa\f\bto\btransliterate\ba\bname.\bThese\bcomparisons\bclearl\f\bindicate\bthat\bthe\bEM\b re-estimation\balgorithm\bgreatl\f\bboost\bthe\bS\t-T\t\bterm\balignment\bperformance.\b

sections.title: 4 C\bncluding Rema\tks
paragraphs: Searching\b is\b a\b necessar\f\b process\b for\b utilizing\b the\b web\b resources.\b It\b is\b not\b onl\f\b useful\b for\b conventional\binformation\bretrieval\band\bextraction\bapplications\bbut\balso\bfor\butilizing\bthe\bWeb\bas\ba\b huge\b linguistic\b corpus.\b Unfortunatel\f,\b both\b searching\b targets\b and\b their\b contexts\b might\b be\b ambiguous\bor\bbe\bexpressed\bin\bs\fnon\fmous\bterms\bor\btranslation\bequivalents;\bsuch\bambiguit\f\bor\b 636 equivalence\b must\b be\bcorrectl\f\b disambiguated\bor\baligned\b in\b order\b to\b mine\b useful\b resources\b and\b miss\balmost\bnothing.\b

A\b statistical\b context-based\b searching\b and\b disambiguation\b model,\b based\b on\b an\b unsupervised\b EM\balgorithm,\bis\bproposed\bin\bthis\bwork.\bThe\bproposed\bcontext-based\bsearching\bmodel\bprovides\b an\b automatic\b framework\b for\b handling\b searching\b problems\b that\b utilize\b contexts\b for\b d\bsamb\bguat\bo\t\band\bflexible\bsy\to\tymous matc\f\b\tg.\bThe\bunderl\fing\bEM\balgorithm\bfor\bparameter\b estimation\b relieves\b the\b need\b for\b exact\b matching\b against\b the\b contexts,\b and\b improves\b searching\b performance\b significantl\f.\b Various\b exact\b or\b partial\b match\b models\b in\b previous\b work\b are\b not\b robust\b across\b domains;\b the\b current\b model\b which\b is\b capable\b of\b s\fnon\fmous\b matching\b largel\f\b overcomes\bsuch\bproblems.\b

The\bproposed\bmodel\bformulates\bthe\bsearching\bproblem\bas\ba\bmachine\btranslation\bproblem\bin\b which\b pieces\b of\b contexts\b are\b accumulated\b to\b enforce\b the\b translation\b probabilit\f\b for\b a\b search\b result\b to\b be\b the\b translation\b of\b the\b source\b quer\f.\b Such\b a\b formulation\b is\b also\b likel\f\b to\b provide\b better\bs\fntactic\bconstraints\bfor\bdisambiguation\bthan\bother\bmodels\bwhich\buse\bthe\bdistribution\bof\b contextual\bterms\bfor\bmeasuring\bcontextual\bsimilarit\f;\bthe\breason\bis\bthat\bthe\blatter\buses\ba\bbag\bof\b words\bwithout\bconsidering\btheir\bdistances\band\bdirections\bwith\brespect\bto\bthe\bsearching\btarget.\b

This\bmodel\bis\bapplied\bto\bthe\bterm\balignment\bproblem\bfor\bsearching\bequivalent\bT\t-S\t\bterms,\b which\b cannot\b be\b done\b based\b on\b direct\b pattern\b match.\b The\b comparisons\b of\b the\b EM-based\b re-estimation\b with\b the\b previous\b character\b or\b word\b based\b matching\b methods\b for\b measuring\b context\bsimilarit\f\bclearl\f\bindicate\bthe\bsuperiorit\f\bof\bthe\bproposed\bEM\balgorithm.\bIn\bthe\bLw-Rw\b model,\b the\b EM\b algorithm\b achieves\b 47~85%\b accurac\f;\b and\b it\b significantl\f\b outperforms\b word-based\bexact\bmatching\bmodels\bb\f\b2~48%\bin\bvarious\bsub-domains.\b  Refe\tences \b Brown,\bPeter\bF.,\bStephen\bA.\bDella\bPietra,\bVincent\bJ.\bDella\bPietra\band\bR.\bL.\bMercer.\b1993.\bThe\b
